JULY 6, FREE!: WRITERS ON THE HARTFORD CIRCUS FIRE

The Mark Twain House & Museum will mark the anniversary of Hartford’s tragic 1944 circus fire on Tuesday, July 6, at 6:30 p.m., with an airing of a CPTV documentary on the Big Top tragedy, followed by a panel at 7:30 p.m. made up of those who have written about the event.

The authors taking part in the panel, "Telling a Tragic Tale: Writers on the Hartford Circus Fire" include novelist Mary-Ann Tirone Smith (Masters of Illusion); poet Paul Janeczko (Worlds Afire); and non-fiction authors Don Massey and Rick Davey, who traced the mystery of “Little Miss 1565,” a girl whose body had never been identified, in A Matter of Degree. The program moderator will be Kathy Maher, Executive Director of the Barnum Museum in Bridgeport. There will be a book signing after the program.

An exhibition of circus fire artifacts curated by Curatorial Assistant Jeff Mainville will be on display in the Great Hall during the program and through July.

The entire evening will be free to the public as part of a grant-funded program series collaboration with the Barnum Museum that jointly commemorates the centennial of Mark Twain’s death and the bi-centennial of P. T. Barnum’s birth.
